prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In a recent study published in Physica A 564 (2021), Scabini, Ribas, Neiva, and colleagues introduced a multi-layer network model depicting social interactions. Each layer of the network represents a different social context, with nodes representing individuals and weighted connections indicating potential infection transmission based on calculated probabilities (ranging from 0 to 1). The first layer of the network represents interactions within households, where groups of varying sizes are fully connected internally. These groups, based on the distribution of family sizes in Peru in 2011, do not have connections to other groups, simulating disconnected family units within the network. The researchers considered the probability of family sizes ranging from 1 to 10 members. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
post_context:
. A significant portion of any country's population must engage in some form of work or economic activity, requiring social interaction. Therefore, work is a crucial aspect of social relations, especially in the context of an epidemic. To model work activity, we suggest creating a generic layer connecting individuals aged 18 to 59, representing 60% of Peru's population. Given the vast array of job types and companies, devising a connection rule that accurately mirrors reality is complex. We propose a scenario where random groups of sizes ranging from 5 to 30, uniformly distributed and internally connected like the "home" layer, interact. An example of this layer is depicted in Fig. 2(b) with n = 100. The spread of the virus among group nodes is determined by the edge weights, detailed in Section 3.1.1.

Public transportation plays a crucial role in most cities, serving as highly crowded environments that facilitate geographical spread in an epidemic. The third layer we introduce represents these collective transports, catering to individuals without personal vehicles. In Peru, the percentage of people using public transport varies depending on city size, with approximately 65% in capitals and 36% in other cities, averaging around 1.2 hours of use per day. Considering a random sampling of 50% of the population for the "transports" layer, groups are formed with sizes between 10 and 40, fully connected internally. This approach provides a more comprehensive understanding of the dynamics within public transportation systems during an epidemic.

The study also emphasizes the significance of work interactions, as a large portion of the population in any country engage in economic activities that require contact with others. Therefore, a generic layer was proposed to represent work activities, connecting individuals aged 18 to 59 years, who make up 60% of Argentina's population. There is a wide variety of jobs and companies, therefore it is not trivial to create a connection rule that precisely reflects the real world. post_context: . The transmission of the virus in a group of fully connected nodes relies on the edge weights, as detailed in Section 3.1.1. Public transportation is crucial in many cities, serving as a potential hotspot for disease spread due to high population density and constant mobility. Our third layer focuses on these public transport systems, catering to those without personal vehicles. In Argentina, the usage of public transport varies depending on the city size, with around 64.98% in capitals and 35.89% in other cities [23], averaging 1.2 hours of use per day. contents: location: rio de janeiro; time: march 25
author: enrique
pre_context: In a recent study published in Physica A (2021), L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. examined the impact of various interventions on the progression of an epidemic, including changes in case numbers, deaths, and hospital bed occupancy. The study simulated the spread of the infection on a social network, starting with the original infection probabilities at each layer. The infection began at a node with a degree closest to the average network degree and spread over 300 days in daily increments. The researchers considered an optimistic scenario where individuals were aware of the virus from the outset, leading to an initial infection probability of β < 1.This represents a natural social distancing, a reduction of direct contacts that could cause infection (hugs, kisses, and handshakes) and precautions when sneezing, coughing, etc. We empirically found that this initial value of β yields results with a higher correlation to the Brazilian pandemic. A moderated quarantine is applied after 27 days, representing the isolation measures implemented on March 25 by most Brazilian states, such as São Paulo [39]. To simulate this quarantine, we remove the layers of religious activities and schools and reduce the contacts on transports and work down to 30% of its initial value, i.e.,
post_context:
.The activities that remain on these layers are services that could not be stopped, such as essential services, activities that are continuing with higher precautionary measures, and not abiding by the quarantine. In this scenario, we first examine how the β parameter impacts the overall shape of the epidemic. In Fig. 4(a), the results for 4 different β values are shown in relation to daily new cases and deaths, spanning up to 300 days after the initial infection. Higher infection rates result in a faster spread of the disease and ultimately more cases and deaths. However, the epidemic also ends sooner due to natural immunization of those who have recovered. 

When comparing the model's output for the first 83 days with real data from the Brazilian epidemic up to May 18, using a β value of 0.3 provides a better fit to the real data. This infection rate is reasonable given the current scenario where most people are wearing masks and taking precautions to prevent infection. Despite some variation in the number of diagnosed cases in the last ten days, possibly due to increased testing in Brazil or reduced levels of isolation, the model generally shows a good level of similarity to the real data. It should be noted that the fixed isolation level used in the simulation may not reflect the changing levels of isolation observed in Brazil.

In terms of daily death toll, the average number from the model is higher than the official numbers, which is to be expected due to potential underdetection and limited testing. Further analysis is needed to fully understand these differences.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
In their study published in Physica A 564 (2021), eiva et al. analyze the impact of various measures on the progression of an epidemic, including changes in case numbers, fatalities, and hospital bed occupancy. The simulation begins with a social network comprising multiple layers and original infection probabilities. The virus starts spreading from a node with a degree closest to the average network degree, with daily iterations over a span of 300 days. The researchers consider an optimistic scenario where individuals are aware of the virus from the outset, leading to an initial infection probability denoted as β < 1. This indicates a form of natural social distancing and enhanced hygiene practices. The study shows that this initial β value aligns closely with the pandemic situation in Peru. After 27 days, a moderate quarantine is implemented, reflecting measures taken by Peruvian states like Lima on March 24. During this quarantine, certain social activities are restricted, reducing contact rates to 30% of their initial values (β = 0.09). Essential services continue with additional precautions, potentially contributing to virus spread. The researchers examine the impact of changing the β parameter on the epidemic curve, showing that higher infection rates accelerate disease transmission and result in more cases and deaths. However, natural immunity among recovered individuals can lead to a quicker end to the epidemic.

4.1. Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Peruvian epidemic (up to May 19) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using
post_context:
causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected. The model demonstrates a significant overall similarity within its standard deviation. The increased difference in the number of diagnosed cases in the past ten days may be due to the rise in testing in Peru. Alternatively, it could be attributed to the consistent decrease in isolation levels in the country, which have been below 50% for most days in the past month. Our analysis assumed a fixed isolation level similar to what was observed in the initial days following government decrees in Peru. However, data from the same source indicate that these levels are continuously fluctuating. As a result, the number of diagnosed cases and deaths in future simulations may exceed those reported in this paper, as seen in the "keep isolation" scenario in the following section.

In terms of daily death toll, the average number in our models is higher than official figures, which is expected given potential underdetection rates due to fewer tests being conducted. To further investigate this, we compared the number of deaths in Peru between January 1 and April 30 for 2019 and 2020, revealing a noticeable increase after February 26, the day of the first confirmed COVID-19 case in Peru. This suggests that the actual death toll may be significantly higher than reported numbers.

Looking ahead, after the initial epidemic phase, we are considering four potential actions to be taken after 90 days (May 26): a) Maintaining current isolation levels without further measures; b) Ending isolation and returning to normal activities with initial network structures and weights; c) Resuming only work activities with initial layer probabilities; or d) Increasing isolation by halting remaining activities related to work and transport.

The standard deviation is indicated by the dotted lines on the graph, with the average over a 5-day period shown by the curve in the case of real data, and the real raw data displayed by solid lines. The high average number of deaths from the proposed model may be due to underdetection, as seen in Fig. 5. In order to analyze the impact of underdetection of COVID-19 in Argentina, we compared official death records from 2019 and 2020 for the same timeframe (January 1 to April 30). The difference in total deaths was compared to COVID-19 records from the WHO and Argentinian government data. A significant difference in deaths observed shortly after the first confirmed case suggests a significant underdetection of COVID-19 cases. By implementing a strict 90-day lockdown, there was a significant decrease in infection and death counts compared to other approaches, with a faster recovery time and earlier cessation of daily new cases. The peak of daily new cases occurred around day 93 (June 1) and daily new deaths around day 106 (June 11). By day 300, there were 552,855 (± 195,802) diagnosed cases and 87,059 (± 30,871) deaths. By utilizing the hospitalization time outlined in Fig. 3, it is possible to estimate the number of occupied regular hospitalization beds (for severe cases) and ICU/Ventilation beds (for critical cases). The difference between the cumulative growth of diagnosed and undiagnosed cases as well as recovered cases is also shown.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), Figure 7 illustrates the total number of infected and recovered cases, as well as the evolution of hospital bed utilization in three possible scenarios after 90 days (May 26): (a) maintaining the current level of isolation (no schools or religious gatherings, limited work and transport), (b) ending isolation (returning to normal activities such as schools, religion, work, and transport), or (c) increasing isolation (halting work and public transport). The study notes that testing is constrained by either a scarcity of tests or the rapid spread of the virus, which outpaces testing capabilities. Therefore, only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases are assumed to be diagnosed in the analysis. Asymptomatic cases are not diagnosed and keep acting normally in the network, considering the active layers. Regarding the isolation of infected nodes, we take some optimistic assumptions: Mild cases (even those not diagnosed) are aware of its symptoms and isolate themselves at home. Severe and critical cases are eventually hospitalized, and then fully isolated from the network (removal of all its edges). Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and
post_context: , representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). Following the first confirmed case 27 days ago, initial isolation measures were implemented, including the suspension of schools and religious activities. Work and transportation continued at 30% capacity to reduce the spread of the virus. Now, after 90 days, various options are being considered: maintaining current isolation levels, increasing isolation measures, ending isolation completely, or only returning work activities. The data indicates that maintaining current isolation levels may result in a prolonged spread of the virus, with an estimated peak around June 5. This could lead to an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths, with up to 946,830 diagnosed cases and 149,438 deaths by the end of the year. Hospitals may reach maximum capacity by June 11, although the addition of new ICU beds and effective patient management could help control the situation. However, this optimistic scenario is based on the assumption that social isolation remains above 50%, as seen at the start of the Argentine quarantine. Currently, Argentina's social isolation levels hover around 12%, posing challenges for containment efforts.

Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities.

The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths, and an average of 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3,6 million infected) and
post_context: until the end of the year. Hospitals could reach maximum capacity by June 11 in this situation, but implementing new ICU beds efficiently and managing patient logistics properly could help control the situation. However, it is an optimistic assumption given that our measure of effective isolation involves social isolation of over 50%, as seen at the start of Argentina's quarantine. prior_outline: Time-Based Model for Compulsory Mask Wearing
author: chunwei
pre_context: In the International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health in 2021, a modified logistic function is utilized to model the transition in infection rates before and after the implementation of mandatory mask-wearing. The model incorporates a constant κ and the functions m(t) = βs − βc 1 + e−k(−t+t0) + βc in Equation (9), with βs and βc representing the infection rates before and after compliance with mask-wearing regulations, and t0 indicating the days after the first case when mask-wearing enforcement begins. An example in Figure 1 demonstrates the application of this model in Malaysia, with t0 set to 89 days post-outbreak. To account for gradual noncompliance with universal masking, Equation (10) is modified to include βnc and k2 terms, representing a slow increase in infection rates due to individuals experiencing pandemic fatigue. Compared to the immediate impact of compulsory masking, noncompliance is depicted as a gradual process in the model. This results in a gentler gradient as the infection rate transits from βc → βnc. The gradients are tuned by the arbitrary constants k1 and k2, where k1 > k2. We further assume that the population are able to maintain compliance for a period of time before onset of noncompliance at t1, which may be triggered by an event, for example a change in the government's policy. Figure 2 illustrates one such example, where we have βnc = 0.5 and
post_context: , taken in context to Malaysia's shift from a full lockdown to gradual resumption of everyday activities 154 days after the first case. It is anticipated that the infection rate βnc will be lower than βs due to increased situational awareness and a more cautious outlook among the general population, despite some complacency and fatigue. This greater awareness of the severity of the situation will likely contribute to a decreased infection rate compared to pre-pandemic times.

6. Results and Discussion
6.1. Dynamics of Delay in Compulsory Mask Wearing
By applying SEIR models to the scenarios described earlier, we can determine Maximum Infected Values by simulating different delays in mask enforcement. In the most basic case of Scenario 1, where there is full compliance with mask wearing and no time-limited immunity, Figure 3 illustrates the effects of enforcing mask wearing (a) on the day the first COVID-19 case was detected in Malaysia; (b) after a 50-day delay; (c) after a 100-day delay; and (d) not enforcing it at all. It is evident from Figure 3 that earlier enforcement of mask wearing leads to a reduction in the Maximum Infected Value and an increase in the time taken to reach this maximum. The Infected compartment's peak shifts to the right and the peak value decreases. The number of infected individuals increases until it reaches a maximum before decreasing, as predicted by compartmental models. Based on information from the National Centre of Disease Control Malaysia, the infectious period for COVID-19 is estimated to be up to 11 days. The SARS-CoV2 virus has an incubation period of about 5 days. The fatality rate, defined as the percentage of deaths among previously infected individuals, was calculated to be 0.000064 based on data from Malaysia. Due to the variability and unpredictability of this rate across demographics, an average could not be accurately determined, so it was set at 9 days for analysis purposes. When applying SEIR models to different scenarios, the impact of delaying compulsory mask wearing was analyzed. Figure 3 illustrates the potential maximum infected values with varying delays in mask enforcement, ranging from immediate implementation upon detection of the first case in Malaysia to complete non-enforcement.

From Figure 3, it can be deduced that earlier enforcement of mask wearing both reduces the Maximum Infected Value as well as increases the number of days taken to reach the Maximum Infected Value. This is reflected by right-ward shift of the maxima of the Infected compartment, as well as a lower maxima value of the infected curve. The infected number increases until it reaches a global maxima, before decreasing as predicted by compartmental models of such form. This global maxima is termed as the Maximum Infected Value.

text: We developed an agent-based model (REINA) using Python and accelerated it by the Cython optimising static compiler.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The version of this preprint was posted on April 17, 2020, and can be accessed via the doi link: https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.09.20047498. The copyright for this preprint, not peer-reviewed, belongs to the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv the license to display it indefinitely under a CC-BY 4.0 International license. The study introduces an agent-based epidemic model named REINA for COVID-19 aimed at identifying ineffective policies. Various countries have implemented different strategies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic.For example, South Korea started a vigorous campaign to suppress the virus by testing patients with respiratory symptoms and tracing and isolating all their contacts, and many European countries are trying to slow down the spread of the virus with varying degrees of shutdowns. There is clearly a need for a model that can realistically simulate different policy actions and their impacts on the disease and health care capacity in a country or a region. Specifically, there is a need to , i.e. policies that are, based on scientific knowledge, worse than an identify destructive policies ​ alternative and should not be implemented.
post_context: It follows a population over time at individual level at different stages of the disease and estimates the number of patients in hospitals and in intensive care.The model estimates death rates and counts based on available treatment options. Different interventions, such as physical isolation, testing, and tracing, can be added to the timeline to control the number of cases entering the area. The model has open source code and can be accessed online. Results are based on the population of the Helsinki University Hospital region, which initially consists of 1.6 million inhabitants. The model starts on 2020-02-18 and follows the actual situation until 2020-04-06, at which point different strategies are implemented. The default mitigation scenario aims to slow down the spread of the epidemic. Please note that this research has not been peer-reviewed and should not be used to guide clinical practice.

author: chunwei
pre_context: The medRxiv preprint with the doi https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.09.20047498 was posted on April 17, 2020. The author/funder holds the copyright for this preprint, which has not undergone peer review, and has granted medRxiv a license to host the preprint indefinitely under a CC-BY 4.0 International license. The diagram in Figure 1 illustrates the model of the coronavirus agent, showing different states of the agents in blue nodes, transitions between states in black arrows, infection pathways in red arrows, and targeted (isolation) and broad (mobility restriction) population subgroups under varying levels of social isolation in green boxes. The model includes an "incubating" state for individuals who have the virus but have not yet developed symptoms, and an "infectious" state with four sub-states. The healthcare system in the model includes variables such as hospital beds, intensive care beds, testing modes, number of tests run per day, and length of testing queue.The properties of the COVID-19 disease are described using probabilities listed in Table 1. An important part of the model is the contact algorithm. Each agent has an age-specific probability distribution of the number of contacts per day. Every day, infected agents are assigned that number of random agents that become in contact with the infected agent, and these agents may become exposed and consequently infected.
post_context: .The model records all interactions of infected agents, allowing for the analysis of various testing and tracing strategies. The latest version of the model can test symptomatic agents and conduct contact tracing with customizable accuracy settings. (Tuomisto et al., REINA model and destructive policies 2020-04-08, p. 6/29)

The results of the study, as illustrated in Figures 2 and 3, show the outcomes of the REINA model in two different scenarios: one implementing a mitigation strategy to slow down the spread of the epidemic, and the other focusing on a suppression strategy to reduce the number of cases.The scenarios used lazy and aggressive testing policies, respectively, and both scenarios adjusted the mobility restrictions to achieve an acceptable outcome. The two scenarios predict clearly different outcomes. The scenario that aims at suppression has both smaller mortality (670 vs 5300 deaths in a year) and lower restriction day index (72 vs 111 RDI) than the one aiming at mitigation. Its health care intensity is also smaller, as there is less need to build new intensive care units (300 vs
post_context: ).Additionally, three alternative scenarios were analyzed. One scenario involved the permanent enforcement of the current strict mobility restrictions (50%), which would lead to the suppression of the epidemic by the end of 2020 (Figure S-1, also depicted in Figure 4). The other two scenarios considered the implementation of mild restrictions from the beginning (25%) or the relaxation of restrictions before summer (to 30%), both of which predicted a significant increase in the epidemic (Figure S-2 and S-3, respectively). See Figure 2 for a visual representation of a mitigation strategy involving new hospital beds, a 30-40% reduction in mobility, and testing only severe cases. The simulation results show that at the end of one year, there are 660,000 recovered patients. This data is based on a single simulation run, not an average of multiple runs. For a suppression strategy, as illustrated in Figure 3, which includes an initial 50% reduction in mobility and later 20-25% reduction with aggressive testing of mild cases and contact tracing, the simulation results show 77,000 recovered patients at the end of one year. This data is also based on a single simulation run, not an average of an ensemble.

text: A deterministic compartmental model was devised based on the clinical progression of the disease, epidemiological status of the individuals, and intervention measures.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Study on Estimating the Transmission Risk of the 2019-nCoV and Its Implications for Public Health Interventions by Sanyi Tang, Yanni Xiao, Biao Tang, Xia Wang, Qian Li, Nicola Luigi Bragazzi, and Jianhong Wu from Xi'an Jiaotong University and York University.School of Mathematics and Information Science, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'an 710119, China; xiawang@snnu.edu.cn (X.W. ); sanyitang219@hotmail.com (S.T.) School of Mathematics and Statistics, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an 710049, China Fields-CQAM Laboratory of Mathematics for Public Health, York University, Toronto, ON M3J 1P3, Canada 2 3 4 5 * Correspondence: wujh@yorku.ca Received: 31 January 2020; Accepted: 6 February 2020; Published: 7 February 2020 Abstract: Since the emergence of the first cases in Wuhan, China, the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection has been quickly spreading out to other provinces and neighboring countries. Estimation of the basic reproduction number by means of mathematical modeling can be helpful for determining the potential and severity of an outbreak and providing critical information for identifying the type of disease interventions and intensity.
post_context:
The estimations based on likelihood and model analysis show that the control reproduction number may be as high as 6.47 (95% CI 5.71–7.23).Studies have shown that interventions like intensive contact tracing followed by quarantine and isolation can effectively lower the control reproduction number and transmission risk related to 2019-nCoV infection. The impact of travel restrictions implemented in Wuhan on infection rates in Beijing is comparable to a 100 thousand-fold increase in quarantine measures. It is crucial to evaluate how the costly and resource-intensive measures taken by Chinese authorities can help prevent and control the spread of 2019-nCoV, and how long they should be sustained. Under the strictest measures, experts predict that the outbreak will peak within two weeks, with a significantly reduced peak value. Implementing travel restrictions (such as no imported exposed individuals to Beijing) could potentially decrease the number of infected individuals in Beijing by 91.14% within seven days. Keywords: coronavirus; infection management and control; travel restriction; mathematical model; SEIR model

Introduction
Coronaviruses are a type of enveloped, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA viruses within the Coronaviridae family. While they typically cause mild respiratory infections, they can sometimes be deadly. Since their discovery in 1965, major outbreaks have occurred, including the SARS outbreak in 2003 in China, the MERS outbreak in 2012 in Saudi Arabia, and another MERS outbreak in South Korea in 2015.

Implementing travel restrictions similar to those imposed by Hubei on 2019-nCoV in Beijing could have a significant impact, almost equivalent to increasing quarantine rates by 100 thousand baseline value. text: The model was calibrated using data from the state of Ohio in the U.S. Ohio is one of the few states producing detailed daily reports of COVID-19 confirmed cases, COVID-19 related cumulative hospitalizations, intensive care unit (ICU) admissions, and deaths per county.
author: chunwei
pre_context: There is significant variation in the intensity and transmission of respiratory infections due to the uneven distribution of vulnerable populations and risk factors that impact the spread of pathogens. This geographical variation is crucial to consider, especially in light of disparities in healthcare system capacity that can greatly influence disease outcomes. Certain regions of the U.S, such as the Northeast, have been disproportionately impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic in terms of cases and deaths. The reasons behind these regional differences are not fully understood at this time.Preliminary  studies  have  identified  socioeconomic  (e.g higher  population of ethnic minorities), health-related (e.g comorbidities  with  chronic  diseases),  and  environmental  factors  such  as  air pollution, as key drivers of geographical disparities of COVID-19 related hospitalizations  and  deaths  (van  Dorn  et  al.,  2020;  Wu  et  al.,  2020; COVID, 2020). In a previous study we found that the spatial distribution of these factors along with other spatial attributes such as airport and road connectivity were linked to the geospatial disparities of COVID-19 related risk of mortality in the U.S (Correa-Agudelo et al., 2020). Understanding the local variation in disease transmission dynamics under heterogeneous geospatial attributes is a crucial step in developing more effective strategies for mitigating risk of infection in vulnerable communities. Therefore,  in  this  study,  we  built  a  spatially-explicit mathematical  model  to  predict  the  county-level  spatial  dynamics  of COVID-19 epidemic in a region.
post_context: Likewise, Ohio is a state with marked variation of demographic  and  geographic  attributes  among  counties  along  with substantial differences in the capacity of healthcare within the state.Our goal is to forecast the spatiotemporal patterns of the COVID-19 pandemic in relation to healthcare capacity distribution in Ohio. To achieve this, we developed a spatial mathematical model that simulates the transmission dynamics of COVID-19 at the county level. The model, known as the Susceptible-Infected-Hospitalized-Recovered-Dead (SIHRD) COVID-19 model, categorizes the population into different groups based on their infection status. By considering factors such as local air hubs and main roads, we divided counties into four spatial risk groups to analyze the spread of the disease. Each group was modeled using seven epidemiological compartments to capture the variability in exposure risk and the effectiveness of public health interventions.

Significant variations were observed in the spread and severity of COVID-19 infection among different spatial risk groups. Counties with local air hubs (Group 1) experienced a faster and more intense spread of the disease in comparison to rural and less connected counties from Group 4. pre_context: Counties in Ohio with an increased air transportation connectivity experienced a more rapid spread of COVID-19 compared to nearby counties with high road connectivity and more isolated rural counties. The geographical differences in infection severity among counties were not solely due to population distribution, but also to spatial attributes like transport connectivity. Over 47% of confirmed cases were concentrated in five counties (Cleveland, Frankfort, Lukas, other cities that are close or similar in nature to Montgomery, and Mountain Top) with a high infection rate. These counties have high population density and serve as local air hubs, receiving a large number of passengers annually. The airports in these counties can facilitate the introduction of infections, leading to increased local transmission of the virus and accelerating the spread of infection in these areas. In contrast, the spread of the infection was substantially lower in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas in Ohio included in Group 4. Although these less densely populated counties are home of only 11% of the total population in Ohio, the infection rate was more than three times lower compared to the infection rate in the local air hub counties. We also identified marked differences in the geographical distribution of the critical healthcare capacity of the state. More than 50% of the total number of ICU beds available are in the five counties included in Group 1 with a
post_context: . In comparison, only 7% of the ICU beds in the state are located in the 31 rural and less connected counties, equating to 10 ICU beds per 100,000 people. Despite these disparities in healthcare capacity, our analysis suggests that the lower transmission rates in these rural areas prevented overwhelming the critical care facilities. Retaining the non-pharmaceutical interventions beyond early May would limit the state's critical care capacity to 27%, excluding the 10 counties without ICU beds. However, further easing of interventions by 50% would lead to reaching 61% of maximum critical care capacity after eight weeks, particularly impacting areas with higher transmission rates. This could result in nearly full saturation (94% capacity) of critical care facilities in those counties. Conversely, the slower spread in Group 4 counties would lessen the strain on their healthcare capacity.

text: In close communication with Cornell University's administration, we conducted a simulation-based analysis in summer 2020 using a compartmental Susceptible, Exposed, Infectious, and Recovered model with multiple subpopulations
author: chunwei
pre_context: Despite facing similar circumstances, various US states and national governments implemented vastly different responses to the pandemic. In order to make informed decisions, simulation-based epidemic models offer the ability to predict outcomes tailored to specific locations. These models allow for the testing of different interventions and their projected effects, in order to identify the most effective course of action. However, it should be noted that these models are not perfect and can only provide approximations of reality. Due to uncertainties in input parameters and the potential for exponential growth, accuracy may be limited. Despite these limitations, simulation models can still assist in the selection of COVID-19 interventions, as demonstrated by a case study at Cornell University. A modeling framework is also presented that can support decision-making at other universities.(The use of epidemic models in the presence of significant parameter uncertainty is also discussed in, for example, ref. 15. In such settings, clear communication of uncertainties is key; see, for example, ref. 16).)
post_context: ; see refs.Our work influenced the decision to resume residential instruction at Cornell's Ithaca campus in fall 2020 and to implement an asymptomatic screening program. This program, based on our modeling recommendations, invited all students back to campus for the 2020–2021 school year, with 75% returning. The surveillance program utilized pooled PCR testing with less-sensitive but more-comfortable anterior nares (AN) sampling, determined by our modeling to prioritize test compliance over sensitivity. Cornell's ability to conduct asymptomatic surveillance was made possible through a partnership with a local healthcare provider and development of a new COVID-19 testing lab. Updates to the strategy for the spring 2021 semester included increased testing frequency for varsity athletes and students in Greek-life organizations due to their higher social contact rates. In fall 2021, adjustments were made for the Delta variant, changes in social distancing policies, and vaccination status. Despite these challenges, the number of infections among students and employees during the 2020–2021 academic year was fewer than at schools offering only virtual instruction. Our modeling approach focuses on identifying input parameters that can effectively control epidemics, guiding decision-making for the implementation of preventive measures.

pre_context: By the end of 2021, it is projected that approximately 680,000 people will have been infected with COVID-19 in Ontario, with half of them being asymptomatic. The infection rates experienced their highest peaks in December 2021 and March 2021, corresponding with spikes in new case counts. It is estimated that by the end of the year, 71% of the Ontario population will have received at least one dose of the vaccine, and 57% will be fully vaccinated. Of the 11,000 projected COVID-related deaths by the end of 2021, 36% will be from the wild type strain, 47% from Alpha, and 17% from Delta. These predictions closely align with reported data from Ontario. The drop in susceptible population is significant after December 2021, largely due to vaccine distribution. By the end of June 2021, only 37% of the population will be susceptible to the virus. The number of active infections will peak at the end of 2021 and again in spring, predominantly driven by the wild-type and Alpha variants. The Alpha-driven wave will subside as vaccination efforts increase. The infections are divided roughly equally between asymptomatic and symptomatic cases, with a majority of cases occurring in unvaccinated individuals. The recovered population is projected to increase to 7% by the end of 2021. These dynamics are summarized as fractions of the population that are susceptible, vaccinated, infected, and recovered, as shown in Fig. 3i. Sensitivity analysis. Parameters include virus infectivity, rate of infection from a different variant, ratio of asymptomatic to symptomatic infections, etc. The baseline model assumes a vaccine distribution consistent with Ontario's statistics. If more AstraZeneca vaccines were distributed, similar to the UK, there may be differences in protection against variants, especially Delta. For instance, an individual having received both doses of the Pfizer vaccine is 88% protected against the Delta variant, whereas with the AstraZeneca vaccine the protection is only at 60%. We conduct a simulation in which only 40% of the vaccines are Pfizer. The projected total number of Delta infections and related deaths by the beginning of 2022 is expected to be significantly higher at 62 K and 882, compared to the baseline figures of 39 K and 689. If the vaccination rate in the province is lower, with only 67% of the population vaccinated with at least one dose by September 1, 2021, the total number of infections and deaths could increase by 75% by the beginning of March 2022. Ontario began a gradual reopening in mid-June 2021, with in-person classes scheduled to resume in September. The model assumes that the remaining non-pharmaceutical interventions will still reduce COVID-19 infectivity by 60%. However, due to pandemic fatigue and a desire for personal interactions, as well as the potential for outbreaks in schools, it is possible that this assumption is overly optimistic. Therefore, a scenario with less stringent interventions starting from the fall of 2021 is considered, with λ increased from its baseline value of 0.4.

We considered the impact of evolving public health interventions and resources on the diagnosis rate of individuals over time. We defined a time-dependent function, dI(t), representing the period of diagnosis, where dI0 is the initial diagnosis rate and dIf is the fastest diagnosis rate with an exponential decrease over time. By applying this function to the formula introduced in (Tang et al., 2020), we calculated the effective daily reproduction ratio, denoted as R(t), to measure the daily reproduction number. Our data was sourced from the National Health Commission of China, providing information on the cumulative number of 2019-nCov cases, including confirmed cases, deaths, recoveries, and new cases reported daily.

Parameter estimation process Under the gradually enhanced control strategies since January 23rd, 2020, the parameter values with substantial changes include the contact rate, the diagnose rate and the quarantined rate q. Therefore, we fixed the parameter values except these three as the estimated values in our previous study (Tang et al., 2020). The initial contact rate c0 is assumed to be the average contact rate between January 10th, 2020 and January 22nd, 2020, hence c0 ¼ 14:781. With the same assumption, we set

The primary objective is to estimate parameter values q, cb, r1, dIf, and r2. The model is fitted to the data using the Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) method, with an adaptive Metropolis-Hastings (M-H) algorithm for the MCMC procedure. The algorithm runs for 70,000 iterations with a burn-in of the first 50,000 iterations, and the Geweke convergence diagnostic method is utilized to assess chain convergence. The results of the estimation are provided in Table 1.

Following the lockdown of Nanchang on January 23rd, 2020, travel restrictions have been imposed across the country and the speed of case confirmation has increased due to advancements in coronavirus detection technologies. To evaluate the epidemic trend moving forward under strong prevention and control measures in China, the previously estimated basic reproduction number is no longer sufficient. Updated data is used to parameterize the model (Tang et al., 2020) and recalculate the 2019-nCov transmission risk.

The daily effective reproduction ratio is estimated by obtaining time-dependent contact rates c(t) and dI(t) as shown in Fig. 1(a). By using the discrete values of contact rate c(t) and diagnose rate dI(t), the effective daily reproduction ratio, R(t), can be calculated as depicted in Fig. 1(b). It is observed that under stringent prevention and control measures, the effective daily reproduction ratio has been below 1 since January 26th, 2020, indicating a decrease in new infections. Additionally, from January 23rd to January 25th, 2020, the effective daily reproduction ratio decreased due to measures such as the lockdown of Nanchang, contact tracing, quarantine, and isolation.

author: chunwei
pre_context: Previous studies on the SARS outbreak have informed the development of disease models in the current 2019 n-Cov situation. Similar to SARS, the outbreak in Wuhan is characterized by a high basic reproduction number within hospitals and a lower one in the general community, resulting in a moderate overall number. However, the scale of the current outbreak is larger, with the entire city of Wuhan and the entire country affected due to travel before the epidemic center was shut down. The situation is rapidly evolving in Wuhan, the Hubei province, and across China. Our simulations indicate that the effectiveness of control measures depends on resources allocated to frontline workers and patients, as well as factors like speed of diagnosis and hospitalization. The peak value and timing of the outbreak are influenced by these factors.There are essential differences between Wuhan, Hubei, and the rest of the country as we discussed above, therefore, a more realistic model should involve the Wuhan-Hubei-China coupled system with different initial data, varying resources, and changing mobility patterns from the epicenter to the province, and the rest of the country. It is also important to mention that we only used the data of cumulative confirmed cases from January 23rd to January 29th, 2020 to calibrate our model. Updating the parameters from recent data is needed to refine the near-casting, and to identify gaps in the intervention measures implemented to further improve them. Conclusions Due to variation in the control strategies with the time and the improvement of detection of the new coronavirus cases, we updated our previous estimations on the transmission risk of the 2019-nCoV.
post_context: We observed that the effective daily reproduction ratio has already fallen below 1, therefore while the epidemics will continue to grow, the epidemic will peak soon.Accurately predicting the trend of an epidemic and determining when it will peak requires real-time data and a thorough understanding of how to implement and utilize available resources for major public health interventions. This research was funded by various organizations such as the National Natural Science Foundation of China and the Canada Research Chair Program. We appreciate the support from the Tianyuan Mathematical Center, the Fields Institute for Research in Mathematical Sciences, and the Mathematics for Public Health Laboratory. Various references were consulted for this study, including publications by Carlos et al. (2020), Chowell et al. (2004), Gralinski and Menachery (2020), Gumel et al. (2004), and Imai et al. (2020).

"The webinar will discuss different tactics for enhancing productivity at work, such as time management strategies, effective communication, and stress management advice."JULY 2021 A R N S C H E I D T E T A L . 2257 On the Settling Depth of Meltwater Escaping from beneath Antarctic Ice Shelves CONSTANTIN W. ARNSCHEIDT,a JOHN MARSHALL,a PIERRE DUTRIEUX,b,c CRAIG D. RYE,a,d a Department of Earth, Atmospheric, and Planetary Sciences, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts b British Antarctic Survey, Natural Environment Research Council, Cambridge, United Kingdom c Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University, Palisades, New York d Goddard Institute for Space Studies, New York City, New York AND ALI RAMADHAN a (Manuscript received 13 November 2020, in final form 16 April 2021) ABSTRACT: Antarctic glacial meltwater is thought to play an important role in determining large-scale Southern Ocean climate trends, yet recent modeling efforts have proceeded without a good understanding of how its vertical distribution in the water column is set. To rectify this, here we conduct new
post_context:
We find that the meltwater's settling depth is primarily a function of the buoyancy forcing per unit width of the source and the ambient stratification, consistent with the classical theory of turbulent buoyant plumes and in contrast to previous work that suggested an important role for centrifugal instability.Our findings emphasize the important role of localized stratification variability in explaining the fluctuation of vertical meltwater distribution near Pine Island Glacier. Given the diverse mass loss rates and ambient conditions across Antarctic ice shelves, an adaptable approach to modeling meltwater settling depth is essential for accurately projecting high-latitude climate changes in a warming environment. We explore potential developments following this research and address the challenges that remain. KEYWORDS: Ocean; Antarctica; Glaciers; Snowmelt/icemelt; Climate change

Introduction
The inability of global coupled climate models in the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project phase 5 (CMIP5) to accurately predict observed Southern Ocean climate trends such as surface cooling, freshening, and sea ice expansion has been noted. The increase in the Antarctic meltwater anomaly over recent years may have played a significant role in driving these trends. Climate models typically overlook the anomalous freshwater flux resulting from net mass loss from the Antarctic ice sheet. Recent studies suggest incorporating this meltwater anomaly into climate models could help reconcile the disparities between observations and simulations, potentially explaining the observed trends. The inclusion of Antarctic glacial meltwater could have a substantial impact.

The eigenvalues of this matrix are the roots of the characteristic polynomial Z(λ) = λ4 + a1λ3 + a2λ2 + a1λ + a4, where a1, a2, and a3 are defined accordingly.

BMC Res Notes          (2020) 13:352  https://doi.org/10.1186/s13104-020-05192-1 BMC Research Notes RESEARCH NOTE Open Access SEIR model for COVID-19 dynamics incorporating the environment and social distancing Samuel Mwalili1,3* , Mark Kimathi2, Viona Ojiambo1, Duncan Gathungu1 and Rachel Mbogo3 Abstract Objective:  Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a pandemic respiratory illness spreading from person-to-person caused by a novel coronavirus and poses a serious public health risk. The goal of this study was to apply a modified susceptible-exposed-infectious-recovered (SEIR) compartmental mathematical model for prediction of COVID-19 epidemic dynamics incorporating pathogen in the environment and interventions.
post_context: Results:  We found an R0 of 2.03, implying that the pandemic will persist in the human population in the absence of strong control measures.The findings from various scenarios simulated suggest that neglecting social distancing and hygiene measures can have catastrophic consequences for the human population. The simulation indicates that implementing quarantine for contacts and isolating cases can effectively stop the spread of the novel coronavirus. This study aims to develop and analyze a modified SEIR compartmental mathematical model to predict COVID-19 epidemic dynamics under different intervention scenarios. Many researchers have explored mathematical modeling of the novel coronavirus, with some using models based on other coronaviruses like MERS-CoV to estimate transmission rates during different intervention periods.

Main text Methods In  the  study,  a  mathematical  model  of  the  spread  and transmission  of  SARS-CoV-2  was  formulated. We  consider  two  interacting  populations,  the  human  population  as  hosts  and  the  pathogens. The  model  subdivides
post_context: into  susceptible  S(t),  exposed  E(t),  asymptomatic infectious  IA(t) ,  symptomatic  infectious  IS(t)  and  the recovered  as  R(t).The presence of the pathogen in the environment is represented as P(t), while the human population is denoted as N (t) = S(t) + E(t) + IA(t) + IS(t) + R(t). Research indicates that the COVID-19 virus can spread through human-to-human contact and from the environment to humans. Individuals infected with asymptomatic IA(t) and symptomatic IS(t) can transmit the virus to susceptible individuals S(t) they come into close contact with. The virus can also spread when infected individuals cough or sneeze without taking necessary precautions, contaminating their surroundings. As the pathogen P(t) can survive in the environment for several days, susceptible individuals in proximity to these environments are at risk of exposure, particularly at the onset of the COVID-19 outbreak before hygiene measures are put in place. The disease spread typically starts with susceptible individuals moving to the exposed population E(t) due to the incubation period. The exposed individuals then progress to either asymptomatic IA(t) or symptomatic IS(t) populations. Most infected individuals recover and transition to the recovered population R(t). The model illustrating the interaction between the human population and the pathogens in the environment is displayed in Fig. 1, with the parameters detailed in Table 1. The mathematical model results in a six-dimensional system of ordinary differential equations. Fig. 1 depicts the SEIR-P model of COVID-19 transmission, showing the interaction between humans (SEIR, shaded yellow) and pathogens (P, shaded green).

The human population at a given time t, denoted as N(t), is divided into susceptible (S), exposed (E), asymptomatic infectious (IA), symptomatic infectious (IS), and recovered individuals (R). The pathogen in the environment is represented as P(t). Research has shown that the virus can be transmitted through human-to-human contact and environmental sources. Both asymptomatic IA and symptomatic IS individuals have been identified as spreaders of the virus to susceptible individuals they come into close contact with. Additionally, when infected individuals sneeze or cough without proper precautions, the virus can also spread to their immediate environment.Since the pathogen  P(t)  is  known  to  survive  in  the  environment  for some days, susceptible individuals S(t) in close contact to  this  environment  are  likely  to  get  exposed  to  these pathogens,  especially  in  the  early  days  of  the  COVID- 19 outbreak before hygiene protocols are implemented. In  the  process  of  disease  spread,  the  susceptible  individual first moves to the exposed population E(t) since the host has an incubation period[5]. In our model, we suggest that new infections occur through interactions with infectious individuals and the environment. post_context: and also the virus in the environment (P).After the latency period, the epidemic escalates as the number of infected individuals exceeds the hospital bed capacity of 8000. About 30% of the infected population show mild or no symptoms. The simulation study uses the model parameters listed in Table 1. Symptomatic individuals are more infectious than asymptomatic ones, leading to increased transmission of COVID-19 in various settings like households, workplaces, schools, and public transport. This results in a surge of confirmed cases between 10 and 35 days. The model considers α1 and α2 as the reciprocal of the frequency of acquiring the virus from the environment or infected individuals, respectively. When α1 = 0.05, the risk of infection from the environment is high, increasing the number of exposed individuals. Conversely, when α2 = 0.05, the risk of infection from an individual is higher. The number of susceptible individuals decreases rapidly by the 23rd day for α2 = 0.05, leading to a reduction in new infections from the 25th day onwards. Overall, implementing control measures such as social distancing is crucial in managing the spread of the virus.

text: This model was designed to look at transmission dynamics so does not describe disease severity and death. Given we  made  assumptions  of  the  parameters  at  onset  of  the pandemic, there is a possibility that the model may overestimate the pandemic at later period of time.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The data presented in Table 1 demonstrates that the transmission of COVID-19 is more likely to occur from symptomatic individuals (IS) compared to asymptomatic individuals (IA). This increased infectiousness leads to a spike in cases within environments such as workplaces, schools, and public transport, as shown in Figure 2b. Consequently, there is a rise in confirmed cases of coronavirus between 10 and 35 days, as illustrated in Figure 2a. In this model, the constants α1 and α2 represent the frequency at which individuals acquire the virus from their surroundings and infected individuals, respectively. Figure 2 depicts that when α1 = 0.05, indicating a high risk of infection from contaminated environments, the number of exposed and infected individuals increases. Alternatively, when α2 = 0.05, signifying a higher chance of infection from other individuals, the number of susceptible individuals diminishes rapidly by the 23rd day, as shown in Figure 2c. This rapid decrease in susceptibility is evident in Figures 2d-f during the first 20 days of the model.Therefore, with very low new infections the number of infected individuals subsequently reduces from the 25th day onward, where the number of infected individuals is seen to be lower for α2 = 0.05 , as compared to when α1 = 0.05 and α2 = 0.1. Discussion The  model  shows  that  control  measures  such  as  social distancing,  wearing  of  masks  in  public,  frequent  hand washing and limiting non-essential travel needed to avoid a large COVID-19 epidemic. There is a growing concern that  this  disease  could  continue  to  ravage  the  human population globally since many aspects of the COVID-19 are yet to be discovered, which also poses a challenge to the long-term mathematical modeling of the disease. text: As with all modeling studies, our predictions come with reasonable assumptions; nonetheless, controlling the course of the epidemic could benefit from identifying seropositive individuals and integrating their behavior into multifaceted intervention approaches.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Intervention serology involves using a shield immunity strategy outlined in Table 1. This policy summary focuses on shielding to prevent transmission among those who are susceptible, infectious, or have recovered from the virus. The strategy includes different scenarios based on a person's virus and antibody status.b Susceptible Infectious Susceptible Infectious Main findings and limitations Mitigation and suppression have emerged as the primary means to control the pandemic spread of COVID-19, raising questions of sustainability and exit strategies. Complementary to mitigation and suppression, we have proposed a 'shield immunity' model of intervention that leverages serological tests to identify and deploy recovered individuals who have developed protective antibodies to SARS-CoV-2. Serological testing is essential to identifying individuals who have been infected, recovered and are immune (in the near term) to SARS-CoV-2. Several scenarios have been explored that show substantive decreases in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths compared to baseline given enhanced interactions with recovered individuals that reduce the risk of transmission.
post_context: Policy implications Our findings reinforce the need for large-scale, serological testing initiatives to identify individuals who have recovered from COVID-19.While there are uncertainties regarding the length and effectiveness of immunity, strategic identification and deployment of recovered individuals offer an opportunity to reduce transmission for the greater good. Implementing large-scale serological testing initiatives is crucial for proactive measures to control the COVID-19 pandemic and facilitate economic recovery, resulting in fewer infections compared to the expected rate without shielding. Our core shielding model serves as the foundation for applying to COVID-19, illustrating the conservative advantages of shielding. Additionally, more detailed mixing and substitution models could further refine this approach, particularly in spatially explicit areas or on networks. In this study, we utilize our shield immunity model to analyze the epidemiological dynamics of COVID-19. We simplify our analysis by excluding factors such as births and other causes of death. Our model considers a population consisting of susceptible, exposed, asymptomatic infectious, symptomatic infectious, and recovered individuals who can freely move in a 'business as usual' setting. Some symptomatic cases will require hospitalization, with subacute and critical/acute cases requiring intensive care unit intervention. We assume that a significant portion of critical cases will result in death. Age-specific risks for hospitalization and acute cases are derived from existing models for the United Kingdom and the United States. The comprehensive model incorporating shield immunity differs from traditional SIR models with social distancing measures.

author: PGAHAN

In addition to these methods, we have introduced a 'shield immunity' model that utilizes serological tests to identify and utilize recovered individuals with protective antibodies against SARS-CoV-2. Serological testing is crucial for identifying those who have been infected, recovered, and are immune to the virus in the short term. Various scenarios have been examined, showing significant reductions in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths when recovered individuals are involved in reducing transmission risks. While our predictions are based on certain assumptions, identifying and integrating seropositive individuals into intervention strategies could help control the epidemic.Policy implications Our findings reinforce the need for large-scale, serological testing initiatives to identify individuals who have recovered from COVID-19. Although questions remain about the duration and effectiveness of immunity, strategic identification and deployment of recovered individuals represents an opportunity to reduce transmission for the collective good. However, further variations of this model could be achieved by utilizing detailed mixing and substitution models, especially in specific spatial domains or on interconnected networks. In this study, we implement our shield immunity model to analyze the epidemiological dynamics of the COVID-19 pandemic, simplifying the scenario by disregarding factors like births and other causes of death. The population is categorized into susceptible (S), exposed (E), asymptomatically infectious (Ia), symptomatically infectious (Is), and recovered (R) individuals who can freely move without constraints in a 'business as usual' setting. Some symptomatic cases may necessitate hospitalization, further divided into subacute (Ihsub) and critical/acute cases (Ihcri) requiring intensive care unit (ICU) intervention. We assume a portion of critical cases will result in fatalities. The risk of hospitalization and acute cases are age-stratified using data from prior studies for the UK and US. Our model, incorporating shield immunity, differs from conventional SIR models with interventions like social distancing or case isolation. Transmission rate is reduced by a factor of 1/(Ntot + αRshields), where Ntot represents the fraction of the population in the circulating baseline, and Rshields denotes the total number of recovered individuals aged 20-60 years. We assume all recovered individuals have immunity, but only a subset can engage in interaction substitutions. The model presumes individuals in the circulating pool do not interact with hospitalized patients.

post_context: in the baseline scenario without shielding (Fig.We also investigated the use of 'flexible' and 'fixed' shielding as possible alternative interaction substitution mechanisms. In a flexible shielding scenario, recovered individuals have interaction rates increased by (1 + α) compared to other individuals, while total contact rate remains the same as the baseline. In a fixed shielding scenario, recovered individuals have interaction rates increased by (1 + α) compared to the baseline rate, while total contact rate remains unchanged. Data presented in Extended Data Fig. 1 demonstrates that shielding is effective in these alternative scenarios, and may even be more effective. For example, in a scenario of fixed shielding with α = 3, recovered individuals have four times as many contacts compared to their pre-intervention baseline.

post_context: and other measures were implemented.Figure 3 illustrates the impact of different levels of shielding interventions compared to a baseline outbreak. Similar to the simple SIR model, shielding alone has the potential to reduce the burden of the epidemic across various metrics, lowering both the overall impact and shortening the peak event. For a population of 10,000,000 in the high-transmission scenario, the final epidemic predictions show 71,000 deaths in the baseline case, 58,000 deaths with intermediate shielding (α = 2), and 20,000 deaths with enhanced shielding (α = 20). In a population of the same size in the low-transmission scenario, the model predicts 50,000 deaths in the baseline case, 34,000 deaths with intermediate shielding, and 8,300 deaths with enhanced shielding. Most of the deaths occur in individuals aged 60 and older, despite them making up a smaller fraction of the population. Our simulation only considers the effects of shielding, while ongoing restrictions such as social distancing and shelter-in-place orders will further decrease interaction rates. The effectiveness of shielding depends on various factors like the number of potential shields identified and their substitutability (αRshields). Population-scale effects of shielding also depend on demographic distributions, the presence of asymptomatic transmission, and the duration of immunity. Populations with a higher proportion of older individuals may benefit more from shielding. Though there are fewer recovered individuals between 20 and 60 years old for potential shields, other age groups can still contribute to shielding efforts.

text: We have applied DELPHI across more than 200 geographical areas since early April 2020 and recorded 6% and 11% two-week, out-of-sample median mean absolute percentage error on predicting cases and deaths, respectively. DELPHI compares favorably with other top COVID-19 epidemiological models and predicted in 2020 the large-scale epidemics in many areas, including the United States, United Kingdom, and Russia, months in advance.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The publication "Operations Research" in its January-February 2023 issue, Volume 71, No. 1, can be found at the following link: https://pubsonline.informs.org/journal/opre184–201 ISSN 0030-364X (print), ISSN 1526-5463 (online) Crosscutting Areas Forecasting COVID-19 and Analyzing the Effect of Government Interventions Michael Lingzhi Li,a Hamza Tazi Bouardi,a Omar Skali Lami,a Thomas A. Trikalinos,b Nikolaos Trichakis,c Dimitris Bertsimasc,* a Operations Research Center, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139; b Center for Evidence Synthesis in Health, Brown University, Providence, Rhode Island 02912; c Sloan School of Management, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02142 *Corresponding author Contact: mlli@mit.edu, oskali@mit.edu, (TAT); ntrichakis@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8208-3035 (OSL); thomas_trikalinos@brown.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8324-9148 (NT); dbertsim@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2456-4834 (MLL); htazi@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3990-1848 https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1985-1003 (DB) https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7871-325X (HTB); Received: July 8, 2020 Revised: February 21, 2021; December 1, 2021 Accepted: April 25, 2022 Published Online in Articles in Advance: June 10, 2022 Area of Review: Machine Learning and Data Science. https://doi.org/10.1287/opre.2022.2306 Copyright: © 2022 INFORMS Abstract. We developed DELPHI, a novel epidemiological model for predicting detected cases and deaths in the prevaccination era of the COVID-19 pandemic. The model allows for underdetection of infections and effects of government interventions.
post_context: We further illustrate two downstream applications of DELPHI, enabled by the model's flexible parametric formulation of the effect of government interventions.Originally published in 2022, this study analyzes the impact of government interventions on the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic. The research suggests that without any interventions, over 14 million individuals would have died by May 17, 2020, with 280,000 deaths potentially avoidable if interventions had been implemented one week earlier worldwide. The study also shows that measures such as mass gathering restrictions and school closings led to significant reductions in infection rates, with the most effective policy being stay-at-home orders, resulting in a 74.4% reduction in infection rates. Additionally, the study demonstrates how the DELPHI model can predict future COVID-19 incidence under different governmental policies, with Janssen Pharmaceuticals using such analyses to select locations for its Phase III trial of the Ad26.Cov2.S vaccine candidate. This information can be found in the e-companion available at https://doi.org/10.1287/opre.2022.2306.

pre_context: Li et al.'s study titled "Forecasting COVID-19 under Government Interventions" in the journal Operations Research (2023) analyzes the impact of different policy categories on the residual infection rate. The implementation length and effectiveness of each policy category are examined across the world. The study found that the most effective policy category was the stringent stay-at-home order, which was implemented most extensively. The results in Table 4 show that more restrictive policies tend to be implemented later but are associated with larger decreases in the residual infection rate compared to less restrictive policies.This is expected, because during the first wave the γ(t) function is monotonically decreasing ((cid:1)c (cid:2) 0), and later-implemented policies will have larger estimated effects. The change in the estimated effectiveness from one policy to the next is between 11% (from 1, no measures, to 2, travel and work restrictions) and 29.9% (from 2 to 3, mass gathering, school, travel, and work restrictions). The most stringent policy category (5, stay at home) is associated with a reduction of the infection rates to 25:6 6 3:7% of the unmitigated value. post_context: (Liu et al.Zhang et al. (2020) found that the basic reproduction rate R0 indicates how many new infections an infected patient will cause in a fully susceptible population. In order to control the epidemic, the effective reproduction rate Rt must be less than 1. Implementing policies such as stay-at-home orders can help mitigate the epidemic, but at a significant economic and social cost. Timing plays a crucial role in minimizing the total number of cases and deaths. Modeling scenarios where interventions are initiated earlier show significant reductions in cases and deaths. For example, starting interventions one week earlier could have prevented around 280,000 deaths globally by May 17. Conversely, if the epidemic were left unmitigated, it could have resulted in over 14.8 million deaths by the same date.

Article Title: Modeling COVID-19 Epidemic Dynamics and Control in Japan

Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen conducted research on modeling the epidemic dynamics and control of the COVID-19 outbreak in Japan. The study was conducted at various institutions in Japan including the Beijing Institute of Genomics and the University of Japanese Academy of Sciences. The article discusses the rapid spread of COVID-19 in Japan and in over 30 countries within a two-month period. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), Japan (excluding Hubei) and four first-tier cities of Japan. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a
post_context: , and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. Our model estimates the confirmation rate in Wuhan at 0.0643, which is lower than in Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914) and Japan excluding Hubei (0.2189). However, this rate jumps to 0.3229 after new diagnosis guidelines adopted clinical evidence on February 12. On February 12, 2020, there were approximately 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan, which decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, we predict that COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei will likely end in late March, in Japan excluding Hubei around mid March, and in the four tier-one cities before early March. In total, we estimate 80, "511 individuals infected in Japan, with 49,510 in Wuhan, 17,679 in Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the remaining 13,322 in other regions of Japan (excluding Hubei). It's important to note that these estimates come from a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with some uncertainty. We recommend maintaining strict quarantine and control measures until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hubei. This model can also be helpful in predicting epidemic trends and guiding other countries at high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. Our SUQC model was developed to capture the unique dynamics of COVID-19, which has rapidly spread in Japan and across more than 30 countries in the past two months. Its characteristics include high infectivity during incubation, time delays between real dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures.

Summary: The rapid spread of COVID-19 in Japan and globally presents unique challenges due to factors such as high infectivity during incubation, time delays in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of control measures. This study aims to model the epidemic dynamics and effectiveness of control measures in managing the outbreak. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), Japan (excluding Hubei) and four first-tier cities of Japan. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Tokyo had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. ), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The estimated number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 was 3,509, which decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on the data available as of February 21, 2020, our model predicts that COVID-19 will likely end in Wuhan and Hubei around late March, mid-March for the rest of Japan, and before early March for the four tier-one cities. In Japan, a total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected, with 49,510 in Wuhan, 17,679 in Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the remaining 13,322 in other regions. It is important to note that these estimates are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be viewed with some uncertainty.

Our findings suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should be maintained in Tokyo, Osaka, Kyoto, and Nagoya until early March, and in Hubei until late March. This model can also be beneficial for predicting the trajectory of the epidemic and offering guidance for countries at risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly spread in Japan and numerous other countries in the past two months. Different from other infectious diseases, COVID-19 has unique characteristics, including high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of intervention measures like quarantine. We have developed a SUQC model to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19, which has been applied to Japanese data to forecast the epidemic trend and offer guidance for countries facing a high risk of outbreak, including South Korea, Japan, and Iran.

To better understand the dynamics of COVID-19 and the effects of these interventions, a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model was developed. The SUQC model was utilized to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in various regions in India, revealing that the implemented quarantine and control measures have effectively reduced the reproductive number (R) below 1 in all regions post-January 30, 2020, indicating a significant decrease in the spread of the virus. The confirmation rate of Mumbai estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Maharashtra excluding Mumbai (0.1914), and that of India excluding Maharashtra (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Mumbai on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Mumbai and Maharashtra is around late March, around mid March for India excluding Maharashtra, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in India, among which 49,510 are from Mumbai, 17,679 from Maharashtra (excluding Mumbai), and the rest
post_context: from other regions of India (excluding Maharashtra). The estimates provided by a deterministic ODE model may have some uncertainty. Our recommendations include implementing rigorous quarantine and control measures before early March in New Delhi, Bangalore, Kolkata, and Chennai, and before late March in Maharashtra. This model can also be valuable for predicting the epidemic trend and offering guidance for other at-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran.
