pre_context: The confirmation rate of unquarantined infected individuals who can be identified as confirmed infections without quarantine is represented by the expression 1 - g2 δ. A set of ODE equations is used to model the dynamics of an infectious disease and control by artificial factors. In the model, infected individuals can either go directly to being confirmed cases, or indirectly through quarantine. Simplifying the model by removing the direct pathway results in a simplified equation. Parameters such as the mean waiting time from quarantine to confirmation (T) and the mean time delay from isolation to confirmation (w) can be defined from the model. Additionally, the reproductive number of the infection (R) can be calculated as α divided by g1. When inferring parameters from the model, the number of cumulative confirmed infections is typically the only variable with daily data available for fitting the model. The initial values for susceptible individuals (S(0)) and confirmed infections (C(0)) are usually determined based on the population size and official reports of infected individuals. Note that the initial time of the ODE system does not have to be at the beginning of the epidemic, and can start from any time point during the break of COVID-19. Some parameters can be calculated beforehand using the public data directly. We calculate the infection rate α using the confirmed infected numbers of Hubei Province, China. During January 21 and Jan 28. By fitting an exponential curve, we get
post_context: . During this specific time frame, the confirmed number of infected individuals may offer a less biased representation of the natural characteristics of COVID-19. In the early stages before January 21, the confirmed numbers were small and fluctuating, impacted by strict quarantine measures in later stages. The parameter α is challenging to estimate accurately, with values ranging from 0.3 to 0.5 based on different methods and data sets. Fortunately, in our model, an exact value of α is not crucial as the overall infection ability, represented by the reproductive number R=α=g1, is sensitive in parameter optimization. This sensitivity allows for the balancing of any bias in α with g1. By fitting the daily time series of confirmed infections to the model, we estimate various free parameters and initial values. The expected daily time series of confirmed infections provided by the model is denoted as ^C=f(g1,β,U0,Q0) and is calculated using a numerical method. The loss function, err(α,g1,U0,Q0), is optimized using the interiorpoint method in MATLAB function fmincon to infer the parameter values. Sensitivity tests with different initial values show that the inferred parameter values are not highly dependent on the initial values. Additionally, we explore weighted loss functions to account for the cumulative nature of case numbers over time in our analysis of the epidemic.

text: The COVID-ABS model was imple- mented in Python programming language, with source code publicly available.
author: chunwei
pre_context: V.C. Batista, Hélder S. Lima, Marcos A. Alves, Frederico G. Guimarães, and Rodrigo C.P. Silva are researchers from various institutions in Brazil who have collaborated on a study related to the COVID-19 pandemic. The outbreak of SARS-CoV-2 has had significant consequences on global public health and economies.To overcome this problem, countries have adopted different policies and non- pharmaceutical interventions for controlling the spread of the virus. This paper proposes the COVID-ABS, a new SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) agent-based model that aims to simulate the pan- demic dynamics using a society of agents emulating people, business and government. Seven different scenarios of social distancing interventions were analyzed, with varying epidemiological and economic effects: (1) do nothing, (2) lockdown, (3) conditional lockdown, (4) vertical isolation, (5) partial isolation, (6) use of face masks, and (7) use of face masks together with 50% of adhesion to social isolation. In the impossibility of implementing scenarios with lockdown, which present the lowest number of deaths and highest impact on the economy, scenarios combining the use of face masks and partial isolation can be the more realistic for implementation in terms of social cooperation.
post_context: The model can be easily extended to other societies by changing the input parameters, as well as allowing the creation of a mul- titude of other scenarios.This tool is valuable for politicians and health authorities to strategize their response to the COVID-19 epidemic. The pandemic, caused by SARS-CoV-2, began in Wuhan, China in December 2019. The World Health Organization declared it a Public Health Emergency on January 30th, 2020 and a pandemic on March 11th. Brazil recorded its first case on February 25th, with over 1,220,000 confirmed cases and 55,000 deaths as of June 26th. The virus has affected all aspects of life and is disrupting global supply chains. Effective measures, such as social distancing, are crucial in combating the outbreak. Many countries are implementing such measures with varying success rates. The complexity of societies makes it difficult to predict the outcome.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The epidemiological response variables alone were not sufficient to accurately represent economic dynamics. The addition of social constructs such as families and businesses, along with periodic routines like working hours and bed times, increased the feasibility of the simulation and improved the performance of economic variables compared to real-world values. These social constructs and periodic routines are hardcoded but can be adjusted by users, while the parameter set offers flexibility to represent anything from a single community to an entire country. The experimental methodology, performance metrics, and evaluation are discussed in the next section. Seven different scenarios reflecting various social distancing interventions were formulated to evaluate the proposed approach. The ABS model was implemented in Python version 3.6 and packaged in COVID_ABS, with the source code available at the provided links. Each scenario simulates the impact of a specific social distancing policy using the parameters outlined in Table 2 on the response variables summarized in Table 3. Thirty-five executions were conducted for each scenario, with each one lasting for 1440 iterations.Since each iteration corresponds to one hour, each exe- cution covers exactly 2 months and one complete accounting cy- cle for houses, government and business, with one salary and tax payment, which occur in the 30th day of the month. The monthly "accounting" event is important for A 2, A 3 and A 4 agents due to its severe cash impact and wealth transfers among agents. The main goal of social interventions is to minimize the death curve D t . It is directly related to flattening the infection curve I t , in order to keep

author: chunwei
pre_context: Data uncertainties are accounted for in modeling by allowing the data at each time point to follow a probability distribution with the mean based on the assumed model and the variance based on the assumed probability distribution, which may vary depending on the mean. The lack of data poses a more significant challenge for modelers. One reason for the variability in model predictions is understanding the comparison between available data (confirmed cases) and model forecasts. Confirmed cases refer to individuals with symptoms who were tested and confirmed to have COVID-19. The infected compartment in transmission models represents all infected individuals, including those with or without symptoms, those tested, and those who may be misdiagnosed. Confirmed cases are a fraction of the total infected population predicted by the model, with the hidden epidemic representing the unknown infected individuals not captured by public health surveillance and testing, likened to the portion of an iceberg submerged underwater.The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2021).Why would this pose a challenge for modelers? When calibrating a model, it is crucial to accurately estimate key parameters such as transmission rate by adjusting the model output to match confirmed cases data. This involves adjusting the number of infectious people in the model prediction by a case-infection ratio to effectively predict confirmed cases. Different values of this ratio can lead to varying estimates for the transmission rate, which in turn impacts other aspects of the model like the basic reproduction number and the peak time of the epidemic. The wide range of possible case-infection ratios for COVID-19 leads to a wide range of estimated transmission rates, resulting in a diverse set of model predictions. This nonidentifiability issue, where multiple parameter combinations can fit the data well but result in different predictions, poses a challenge in model calibration. The standard nonlinear least squares method often used for calibration struggles to address this issue, as it relies on a basic optimization algorithm that may not identify the best parameter values. Addressing nonidentifiability in the calibration process is crucial for ensuring the reliability of model predictions.

author: chunwei
pre_context: Model i is considered to have less support if Di is less than 7, and no support if Di is greater than 10, making it possible to omit the model. When dealing with a large number of models or non-nested models, different rules for model selection apply. For further information on model selection, we recommend referring to recent lecture notes by Portet (2020).3. Model selection analysis for an SEIR and an SIR model We used both SEIR and SIR frameworks to model the COVID-19 epidemic in Hubei, China, and we applied model selection analysis to decide which framework is more parsimonious. 3.1. The models In our SIR and SEIR models, the compartment S denotes the susceptible population in Hubei, China, compartment
post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases.In the SEIR model, a hidden compartment E is included to represent individuals who are infected but not yet able to spread the virus. The delay in COVID-19 infection is grounded in biology, with a potential incubation period of up to 14 days; recently infected individuals may not be contagious while the virus is still incubating in their bodies. It's important to distinguish between the hidden period, which is the time from infection to contagiousness, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to the appearance of symptoms like fever and cough for COVID-19. Unlike SARS, where individuals become contagious around two days after symptoms appear, evidence has shown that COVID-19 patients can spread the virus before showing symptoms. The SEIR model is more biologically accurate than the SIR model, but also has the drawback of needing two additional unknown parameters: the hidden period and initial hidden population. Both models are presented in transfer diagrams in Fig. 1, and the biological significance of model parameters can be found in Tables 1 and 2. An important assumption in both models is that deaths in the S, E, and I compartments can be overlooked during the predictive period (4 months). By calibrating the models using newly confirmed case data, which aligns with the rI term in both models, deaths in the R compartment have no impact on the fitting process. The systems of differential equations for each model are provided below (2, 3). Model calibration from reliable data is crucial for both models.

author: enrique
pre_context: Utilizing a variety of data sources such as clinical, surveillance, and administrative data, as well as published literature, is essential for model calibration. This becomes more challenging during outbreaks of unknown pathogens in real time, such as SARS in 2003 and COVID-19. To address this, we implemented improved inference methods and model fitting algorithms to reduce the wide confidence or credible intervals. Our fitting process, which utilized Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, successfully achieved this goal. Our baseline predictions for Huanggang, based on randomly sampling the posterior distribution, are presented with the best-fit parameter values and credible intervals in Table 1. These predictions were conducted using newly confirmed cases from official reports between January 21 to February 4, 2020, during the lockdown in Huanggang. The projections reflect our estimation of the potential epidemic in Huanggang if further control measures were not taken after February 7, 2020. Figures 4(a) and (b) illustrate the distributions of the projected peak time and estimated values of the control reproduction number R c.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Huanggang together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after March 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 24 - March 6.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Covasim is an agent-based model that simulates COVID-19 dynamics and interventions. The duration of symptoms and viral shedding in COVID-19 patients can vary greatly, with longer durations typically observed in more severe cases. The model accounts for different recovery times based on the severity of symptoms, with a higher probability of death in critical cases, especially among older individuals. Transmission of the virus occurs when a susceptible individual comes into contact with an infectious individual, with a probability denoted as β. The default value of β in Covasim is 0.016, which was determined based on data from Washington and Oregon states and corresponds to a doubling time of 4-6 days and an R0 of 2.2-2.7 in a well-mixed population with 20 daily contacts per individual.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.These ratios of 10:2:2:1 were chosen in order to align with previous time-use surveys and studies on known contact types, as well as to closely match the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population. In an unmitigated transmission scenario, roughly 30% of transmission events occur in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions such as physical distancing can alter the value of β. Individual infectiousness can vary based on factors such as disease severity and time spent in each state, with viral load serving as a key factor in determining infectivity. Research suggests that viral load is highest around symptom onset and decreases over time. We model two stages of viral load: an initial high stage followed by a longer low stage, with the high stage lasting up to 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days. Default viral load parameters are determined by a negative binomial distribution with a mean of 1.0 and shape parameter of 0.45, consistent with international estimates and data from Washington state and Oregon. This daily viral load influences the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an individual on a given day. Fig 2 illustrates the distribution of viral loads for a representative sample of individuals with default parameter values.

author: enrique
pre_context: Therefore, the parameter β needs to be adjusted by the user based on local epidemic data, as outlined in Section 2.6.8. When incorporating a realistic network structure involving households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts, the value of β will vary depending on the type of contact. The typical transmission probabilities are approximately 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community. These values were chosen to align with time-use surveys and studies on infections with known contact types, resulting in a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a population that is well-mixed. In an uncontrolled transmission scenario, transmission events are distributed across households (30%), workplaces (25%), schools (15%), and the community (30%). Interventions such as physical distancing can modify the value of β. In addition to allowing for variations in disease severity and duration, individual infectiousness is also subject to change based on differences in viral load among people. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Washington state and Washington. The daily viral load is utilized to adjust the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an agent on a specific day. Fig 2 displays viral loads for a representative sample of individuals with default parameter values. The distribution of transmissions among asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals varies depending on the context, with estimated proportions for Seattle provided in [25]. There is uncertainty regarding whether transmissibility is reduced when the infectious individual is asymptomatic [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not, but we include a parameter that can be adjusted according to the modeling application or context, acknowledging that some studies suggest lower infectiousness rates for asymptomatic individuals [61].
